Retirement and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled    Entering old people's and nursing homes as well as residential facilities for the disabled is only permitted under certain conditions:  â¢	Visitor limit: a maximum of two visits are permitted per resident and day, plus a maximum of more  	o	two people per day to accompany underage residents of residential facilities for the disabled,  	o	two people per resident in need of support per day if they perform regular support and care tasks.  	o	Exceptions: Visits as part of palliative care and hospice care, pastoral care and to accompany critical life events.  â¢	If it can be credibly demonstrated that a negative PCR test cannot be presented for reasons of lack of availability, an untimely evaluation or due to the unpredictability of the official activity to be performed, operators may exceptionally admit persons even if they have 3G proof submit. This also applies to operators.  â¢	The planned measures must not be disproportionate or lead to unreasonable hardship.    The following generally applies to visitors:  â¢	Operators may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they can show 2G+ proof.  â¢	Exceptions: Accompanying persons of underage residents of inpatient residential facilities of the disabled aid and for visitors of palliative care and hospice patients.  â¢	Operators may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they wear an FFP2 mask throughout the visit or stay.    The following applies to employees:   â¢	Operators may only let employees in if they can show proof of 2.5G.  â¢	Employees must wear an FFP2 mask in closed rooms.  â¢	This also applies to external service providers, statutory representatives, bodies responsible for care supervision or members of established commissions.    The following applies to operators:  â¢	Operators of old peopleâs and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled may only admit residents to new admissions if they can show proof of 2.5G. If no 2.5G proof can be provided, quarantine or other suitable measures should be implemented in accordance with a Covid-19 prevention concept.  â¢	Operators of retirement and nursing homes must offer residents an antigen test or PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 at least every seven days, but if they have left the home within this period.  â¢	Operators must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.    **Vienna**  Retirement and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled  â¢	Visitors must provide proof of 2G+, whereby the negative PCR test must not be older than 48 hours; A maximum of two visitors per day per resident.  â¢	Employees, owners and operators require 2G proof. If the 2G proof cannot be provided, a negative PCR test must be submitted. In exceptional cases, if it is absolutely necessary to maintain operations, a negative PCR test, which must not have been taken more than 72 hours ago, can be presented. In addition, a PCR test is prescribed twice a week (=professional group screening).  â¢	Owners, operators and employees of inpatient hospitals who have recovered from an illness with the Omicron variant after January 15th, 2022 must present a negative antigen test to an authorized body twice a week for four weeks after the infection has been overcome instead of the PCR tests.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/hh6W3 .[Nationwide measures]  https://archive.vn/4E6Wl [Coronavirus: current measures]  https://web.archive.org/web/20220201224111/https://www.ris.bka.gv.at/Dokumente/BgblAuth/BGBLA_2022_II_34/BGBLA_2022_II_34.html [4th COVID-19 Measures Ordinance and amendment of the 4th COVID-19 Measures Ordinance (1st amendment to the 4th COVID-19-MV]  https://archive.vn/b1gXo#selection-1205.0-1265.290 [Vienna]  https://archive.vn/UtGXz [Vienna COVID-19 Accompanying Measures Ordinance 2022]

https://archive.vn/5KYZt    Prevention of unjustified dismissals or reductions in the number of jobs;  Continuation of paying salaries to employees working from home;  Creation of additional 50,000 paid public jobs in 2020;  Provision of a lump-sum payment for 600,000 unemployed persons;  Simplification of the application procedure for a lump-sum payment on the web portal of the Ministry of Labour and Social Protection;  Involvement to a self-employment programme;  Expansion of the unemployment insurance coverage to 20,000 persons;  Scholarships for those who have had breaks in vocational training courses;  Use of reserves of 2019 of the State Social Protection Fund for the period from April until December 2020 to ensure the sustainability of social payments (pensions and benefits) to the population;  Extension of the payment of targeted state social assistance to low-income families until the 1st day of the month following the end of the quarantine regime;  Expansion of the coverage of targeted state social assistance program;  Payment of annual tuition fees from the state budget (24 million US dollars) for students from socially vulnerable families;  Allocation of funds from the state budget to meet the needs of citizens for medical masks (2,7 million US dollars);  Temporary increase of existing discount limits on electricity use (5,9 million US dollars).

The entry ban on the countries was lifted on December 23, however, sanitary measures remain in place. The ban still remains on countries that are considered very high-risk    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211231181838/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/faq/

The entry ban on the countries was lifted on December 23, however, sanitary measures remain in place. Belgium operates a colour code that determines entry protocols based on the country of arrival. (Red(High risk), Yellow(Moderate risk) and Green(Low risk)). Stricter rules apply for countries considered to be very high risk.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211231181838/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/faq/

Belgium operates a colour code that determines entry protocols based on the country of arrival. (Red(High risk), Yellow(Moderate risk) and Green(Low risk)). Stricter rules apply for countries considered to be Very High Risk.    People from countries categorized as "VERY HIGH RISK COUNTRIES" outside the European Union or Schengen area are not allowed entry into Belgium.     Vaccinated people from ZONES catorized at "RED" outside the European Union or Schengen area are required to get tested before your arrival in Belgium (PCR or RAT), regardless of the length of stay and to get also tested (PCR) on day 1 and 7 after arrival in Belgium. They would also have to stay in quarantine until the negative result of your test on day 1.    Those coming in from a GREEN or ORANGE zone do not need to get tested or quarantine.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220127111112/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/travels/

Vaccinated people from ZONES catorized at "RED" outside the European Union or Schengen area are required to get tested before your arrival in Belgium (PCR or RAT), regardless of the length of stay and to get also tested (PCR) on day 1 and 7 after arrival in Belgium. They would also have to stay in quarantine until the negative result of your test on day 1.    Those coming in from a GREEN or ORANGE zone do not need to get tested or quarantine. Wearing a face mask remains mandatory for everyone in the following areas:    - on public transport from entering the indoor areas of the airport, the station, on the platform or a bus, (pre-)metro, tram, train stop or any other means of transport organised by a public authority. Public transport operators and all bus operators carrying out public transport services are not required to cover their nose and mouth, insofar as the driver is well-isolated in a cabin on the one hand, and a poster and/or sticker indicates to users the reason why the driver is not wearing a mask on the other;  - in the indoor areas of organised collective transport (i.e. transport organised in advance with a clear itinerary or final destination and a vehicle with at least 9+1 seats (passengers + driver)), this does not apply to public transport operators, insofar as the driver is well-isolated in a cabin on the one hand, and a poster and/or sticker indicates to users the reason why the driver is not wearing a mask on the other;  - in establishments and places where close-contact professions are carried out. This applies to service providers and customers where there is direct physical contact between the service provider and the customer or where the distance of 1.5 metres cannot be guaranteed between the service provider and the customer for a duration of at least 15 minutes;  - the publicly accessible areas of companies, associations and services;  the publicly accessible areas of commercial establishments, shops and shopping centres;  libraries, game and multimedia libraries;  - in the indoor areas accessible to the public of establishments belonging to the sports sector, including fitness centres and establishments that may remain open in accordance with Article 7, Â§1 of the Royal Decree, subject to items 11 and 12 below;  - in places of worship and buildings intended for the public practice of non-denominational moral services;  when moving around in public and non-public parts of courthouses and courtrooms and, in other cases, in accordance with the guidelines laid down by the Chairman;  - the publicly accessible areas of government buildings;  establishments and places where catering activities are permitted, both for staff and those customers who are not seated at a table or at the bar;  locations where authorised private gatherings and activities in an organised context take place with more than 50 people indoors or 100 people outdoors;  - venues for events of any size, including mass events, authorised outdoor conferences and authorised sports competitions;  trade fairs, including exhibitions;  - other locations where access is organised in accordance with the Cooperation Agreement of 14 July 2021 with regard to the CST. *the indoor areas of schools and educational institutions;  - the indoor areas of the after-school care facilities for primary school children.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220127105912/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/faq/

The holding of face-to-face group classes for adults in language centers, educational centers and other training centers and schools is suspended. Conducting face-to-face group classes for children in language centers, educational centers, personal development support centers and other training centers and schools is allowed at a physical distance of at least 1.5 m and not more than 5 people in a room, wearing protective face masks, hand hygiene, regular airing every hour and disinfection. Restrictions do not apply to special education support centers. he attendance of 50% of the classes in the schools in the municipalities with a 14-day morbidity between 250 and 500 per 100,000 population has been terminated. Attendance training is carried out according to a schedule approved by the Minister of Education and Science.  /web/20220124222106/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

Employers and appointment bodies in all administrations within the meaning of Art. 1 of the Administration Act organize the work process of the employees, as:  (a) establish working hours with variable limits and the start of the working day between 7.30 and 10.00, unless this is not possible depending on the nature of the work;  (b) assign remote work to at least 50% of staff, unless this is not possible depending on the nature of the work.  Employers in hospitals, complex oncology centers, dialysis centers, hospices and nursing homes organize the work process by admitting to work only employees with valid documents for vaccination, illness or testing within the meaning of this order.   /web/20220124222106/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

The holding of all mass events, such as music and other festivals, fairs, folklore initiatives and others of such nature, shall be suspended.  Visits to libraries, museums, galleries, cinemas, theaters, circus performances, concerts and other indoor performances are suspended. Visits to fitness centers, sports halls and clubs, swimming pools and complexes, balneotherapy (medical SPA) centers, SPA centers, wellness centers and thalassotherapy centers are suspended. Visits to shopping malls, shops with a net retail area of ??over 300 square meters, bazaars and indoor exhibitions shall be suspended. Exceptions are allowed for shops offering mainly groceries, pharmacies, drugstores, opticians, pet shops, banks, postal and courier service providers, insurers, payment service providers and telecommunications operators' offices, whether they are stand-alone or located in a shopping center type Mall. An exception is allowed for medical establishments and vaccination points located on the territory of shopping centers.  /web/20220124222106/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

No change in policy.    - Limit the number of guests to the smallest possible number, and in accordance with the currently valid orders of  the competent crisis headquarters - up to 50 people indoors. The presence of only celebrants and necessary  guests (eg high school graduates) and the necessary staff is recommended, with as few guests as possible (eg  family members). The presence of persons from abroad is not recommended, as well as persons over 65 years  of age.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220115114451/https://www.zzjzfbih.ba/covid-19/

Policy change from maximum of 50 people to 30 people.    The new Order , which is in force as of today, January 13, 2021. year, the number of persons who can stay indoors at the same time from the previous 50 was reduced to 30, while more than 100 people can stay outdoors.  All gatherings within the stated limits must take place in a space that allows a mandatory physical distance of at least 2 meters between persons (except members of the same household).  Exceptionally, the new Order allows the organization of larger gatherings indoors and outdoors, provided that the size of the space allows the implementation of hygienic and epidemiological measures, but not more than 60 people indoors or 200 people outdoors, provided that all participants together have a negative antigen test (not older than 24 hours) or a PCR test (not older than 48 hours) or a certificate of overcoming COVID-19 (not older than 4 months) or a certificate of completed vaccination (not older than 6 months after receiving the second vaccine doses, ie 9 months after receiving the third vaccine dose).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220115120320/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/822/od-danas-na-snazi-nove-naredbe-kriznog-stozera-federalnog-ministarstva-zdravstva-koje-je-usvojila-vlada-fbih

No change in policy.    Inform passengers about the importance of maintaining a physical distance of at least one meter from each other.    The number and arrangement of passengers by seats must be such as to allow the prescribed distance (1-2 m, or one empty seat) between them. Limit the capacity to seats so that one person sits in a row, in such a way that they sit alternately in the left and right seats. Places not used should be marked with a tape or warning sign. We recommend that you do not allow yourself to stand and hold the handrails while driving, except when entering and exiting the vehicle.    All passengers must wear protective masks, in accordance with previous orders.    Increased presence of auditors in vehicles is recommended. In public urban transport in particular, to ensure compliance with measures by passengers and the permitted number of passengers per vehicle.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220114143341/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/preporuke

It is mandatory to wear masks at public transport stops, markets / open markets and other places where there is a greater fluctuation in population.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220115120320/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/822/od-danas-na-snazi-nove-naredbe-kriznog-stozera-federalnog-ministarstva-zdravstva-koje-je-usvojila-vlada-fbih

CONDITIONS FOR ENTRY TO BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA         (Article 2)    A foreigner who meets conditions for entry to BiH prescribed by Law on Aliens, may enter BiH if he/she at the BiH Border Crossing Points presents any of the following:    negative PCR test or rapid antigen test on SARS-CoV-2, not older than 48 hours if he/she comes from an European country, and if he/she comes from another country, not older than 72 hours until arrival at the border crossing point ofBosnia and Herzegovina,    certificate that a person has received the second dose of vaccine for COVID-19 before more than 14 days before the arrival to a Border Crossing Point of BiH or has received one dose before 14 days and more before the arrival to a Border Crossing Point of BiH, if it is a single dose vaccine,    certificate issued by doctor showing that he/she has recovered from COVID-19 in the previous period from 14 to 180 days until the arrival to a Border Crossing Point of BiH.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220113193549/http://www.granpol.gov.ba/Content/Read/76?title=Stranci&lang=en

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in BiH? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Private and public clinics throughout BiH perform PCR and serological COVID-19 tests. Payment is due in full at the time of the test and current prices are roughly 100 convertible marks (km) for PCR and 40km for antigen.  Turnaround of results and availability of testing appointments vary based on the city yet clinics in most large cities have testing options daily and return results within 24 hours.  A list of clinics known to provide COVID-19 testing in BiH can be found on our website here  Public Health Centers (Dom Zdravlja) test symptomatic individuals regardless of nationality, free of charge. To arrange a test, contact your cantonâs health center for additional guidance.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220114112145/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The new order continues to instruct the competent authorities in the cantons / counties, as well as the health institutions in the cantons / counties, to provide COVID-19 vaccination points at the level of each municipality in order to make COVID-19 vaccination more accessible to the public. They are also required to organize vaccinations against COVID-19 every working day, at least three times a week until 20:00, at least one day during the weekend, and at least once a week at places of larger public gatherings.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220115120320/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/822/od-danas-na-snazi-nove-naredbe-kriznog-stozera-federalnog-ministarstva-zdravstva-koje-je-usvojila-vlada-fbih

There are several measures travelers must take in order to enter the country. Vaccinated or recovered individuals must complete an entry form and present a negative test.  Not recovered and not vaccinated individuals must fill out the entry form, present a negative test, and turn in a second negative test between 4-7 days upon the arrival.     The government of Switzerland had a ban in place for "countries with a variant of concern", which meant that travelers from these destinations were prohibited from entering the country. However, as of now, there are no countries under this category.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20220105160134/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/empfehlungen-fuer-reisende/quarantaene-einreisende.html    http://web.archive.org/web/20220105160156/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/empfehlungen-fuer-reisende/liste.html

There are several measures travelers must take in order to enter the country. Vaccinated or recovered individuals must complete an entry form and present a negative test.  Not recovered and not vaccinated individuals must fill out the entry form, present a negative test, and turn in a second negative test between 4-7 days upon the arrival.     The government of Switzerland had a ban in place for "countries with a variant of concern", which meant that travelers from these destinations were prohibited from entering the country. However, as of now, there are no countries under this category.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20220115214529/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/empfehlungen-fuer-reisende/quarantaene-einreisende.html
Measures were eased for vaccinated travellers entering Switzerland; any form of testing was dropped.

Masks are required in all public spaces.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20220105160156/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/empfehlungen-fuer-reisende/liste.html

Vaccines are generally available in Switzerland for people of all age groups.       Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20220105154631/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html#-134524438

Although there are some groups that are highly encouraged to get the jab, there's no vaccine prioritization plan in Switzerland. At this point, the inoculation campaign has become universal. Anyone above 5 years old can receive the vaccine.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20220115214734/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html

No evidence of policy change.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220115214734/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html

No evidence of policy change.     http://web.archive.org/web/20220115214734/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html

All pupils of primary and secondary education will undertake weekly testing at school.   Masks must be worn when there are more than 50 people in a room.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220115205410/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/education/high-schools

For those who are not vaccinated, access to most services is forbidden without a proof a covid-recovery.   For those who are vaccinated, masks must be worn in public indoors spaces.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220130140346/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/infection-and-general-measures/o-n-t-system-vaccination-past-disease-test

For those who are not vaccinated, access to public events of more than 20 people is forbidden without a proof of covid-recovery.   For those who are vaccinated, public events must be limited to 1,000 participants and FFP2 masks must be worn inside.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220130141918/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/culture/festivals

Public and private events can take place with a limit of 100 participants outdoors and indoors. If more than 20 people are present at the event, all those over 12 years of age must prove upon arrival either that they are vaccinated or that they have recovered from covid. Masks must be worn indoors.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220130141404/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/culture/social-events
Masks must be worn inside public transports  https://web.archive.org/web/20211118234408/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/face-masks-and-respirators/public-transport-taxi
No measure found  https://web.archive.org/web/20211227130850/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/free-movement-people/measures-free-movement
No measures found  https://web.archive.org/web/20211227130850/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/free-movement-people/measures-free-movement

Different regulations applies to different countries. Most travelers must be tested, except those who are vaccinated. Travelers coming from a country listed as dark red must quarantine until they receive the results of their tests taken between 5 and 7 days after their arrival, if they are not vaccinated. All travelers must fill an Arrival Form.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211227131830/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/foreigners/possibilities-and-obligations-foreigners-when-entering-cz

This compensation applies to cases where employees are ordered to quarantine or to be isolated due to COVID-19. The amount of the support is set at 80% of eligible costs (compensation of wages paid to employees + the corresponding amount of statutory contributions), but a maximum of CZK 39,000 per employee and month. For employees, this means that they are in obstacles and receive a wage compensation of 60% of average earnings.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220130144000/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/compensation/antivirus-plus-forced-limitations-service-operation-and-quarantine

No evidence that the debt relief policy of 2020 is still in place.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220115211415/https://www.vlada.cz/en/media-centrum/aktualne/measures-adopted-by-the-czech-government-against-coronavirus-180545/
There is an updated government website to provide information  https://web.archive.org/web/20220130144000/https://covid.gov.cz

Tests are available for all, they can be free of charge with a doctor request, paid for by the health insurance under certain conditions, or if none of the conditions apply, self-paid.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220127065130/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/testing/how-get-tested

Self-reporting is recommended and tracing centers are organizing the tracing effort.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220130145042/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/infection-and-general-measures/how-does-tracing-work

Masks are required in most indoors public spaces and are recommended in outdoors public space where social distancing cannot be kept.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211227173017/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/face-masks-and-respirators/indoors

Vaccination is available to all over 5 and is funded either by public health insurance or self-paid.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211227173641/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/register-vaccination/vaccination-nutshell

For all, preventive measures must be followed and masks must be worn inside care facilities.  For those non-vaccinated, a negative test or a proof of covid-recovery is required to access the facility.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220130150527/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/hospitals-and-sanitary-facilities/visits-social-facilities

Vaccination is available to all over 5 and is funded either by public health insurance or self-paid.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211227173641/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/register-vaccination/vaccination-nutshell
Vaccination is available for those over 5 years old.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211227173641/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/register-vaccination/vaccination-nutshell

Vaccination is paid either by EU public health insurance or must be self-paid by those who do not have this insurance.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211227173641/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/register-vaccination/vaccination-nutshell
No changes in policy
No changes to previous policy.

Schoolchildren are back at their desks <> in Germany, with students in every state except Thuringia required to be present at in-person classes.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220104090933/https://www.thelocal.de/20220103/german-schools-start-up-against-as-omicron-cases-rise/  In Thuringia, Students who  do not participate in the specifically offered tests or who cannot provide proof of testing and who are not exempt from the obligation to participate in the specifically offered course  in accordance with <> are prohibited from entering the school building.  Distance learning takes place for these pupils,  in  which pupils are obliged to participate. This does not affect the containment of the spread of the coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 in day-care facilities ,other youth welfare, schools and sports operations. https://web.archive.org/web/20211229140809/https://bildung.thueringen.de/fileadmin/2021/2021-12-28_TMBJS_Allgemeinverfuegung_Kita-Schule-Jugendhilfe-Sport.pdf
No changes in policy

As of 7.01.2022, Germany has introduced a nation-wide '2G plus rule': This means that accessing restaurants and bars will only be possible with recovery/vaccination certificate AND a negative LTF test: https://archive.ph/fMcNj

2G rule also applies nationwide and regardless of incidence in the retail trade. Excluded are shops for daily needs. Access must be controlled by the shops.   In gastronomy (restaurants, cafÃ©s, bars and pubs, etc.), only vaccinated and convalescents should have access with a daily test or with a booster vaccination (from the day of the booster vaccination).  Indoor clubs and discotheques will remain closed until further notice and dance performances will be banned.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220126181506/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-regeln-und-einschrankungen-1734724  2G applies in retail shops, at cultural and leisure facilities (e.g. in restaurants, bars, hotels, theatres): Shops selling items for daily needs (e.g. supermarkets, pharmacies, drugstores, bookshops) remain open for everyone. A federal state can close restaurants or restrict hotel stays in a county if there is a high number of infections.  https://archive.vn/0kvjc#selection-8777.0-8779.90

For New Year's Eve, a general ban for public events and public gatherings is in place. https://web.archive.org/web/20211231193527/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-silvester-1825108
No changes in above mentioned policy
Policy remains in place: https://archive.ph/fMcNj

Facilities and events of cultural and leisure activities (such as cinemas, theatres, etc.) may only be visited by vaccinated and convalescents (2G). This applies nationwide and is independent of the incidence. There are exceptions for people who cannot be vaccinated or for whom there is no general vaccination recommendation. https://web.archive.org/web/20220126181506/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-regeln-und-einschrankungen-1734724
No changes to previous policy
Policy remains in place: https://archive.ph/fMcNj

Private meetings in public or private spaces attended by persons who have not been vaccinated or recovered shall be limited to one's own household and to a maximum of two other persons in another household. Children up to the age of 14 do not count.  In order to slow down the Omikron variant, private gatherings of vaccinated and convalescents are only allowed with a maximum of ten people.  Children up to the age of 14 do not count.  Once an unvaccinated person attends a gathering, the contact restrictions that apply to unvaccinated individuals apply.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220126181506/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-regeln-und-einschrankungen-1734724
No changes to previous policy, 3G rule still in place.
No changes to previous policy, 3G rule in place: https://archive.ph/fMcNj

In public transport and regional and long-distance trains, the 3G rule applies in addition to the mask requirement. If passengers have not been vaccinated or recovered, they must carry proof of a negative corona rapid test when using a means of transport. At the start of the journey, the test acceptance must not be more than 24 hours ago.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220126181506/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-regeln-und-einschrankungen-1734724  https://archive.vn/0kvjc#selection-8777.0-8779.90
No changes in policy.
Recommendation to stay at home is still in place: https://archive.ph/fMcNj
No changes in policy.
No changes to previous policy, 3G rule in place: https://archive.ph/fMcNj

In principle, entry is possible from: EU member states; states associated with Schengen: Iceland, Norway, Switzerland and Liechtenstein; other countries from which entry is possible in light of the epidemiological situation assessment by the EU.  Entry from any other country for any purpose (including visits and tourism)  is only possible for fully vaccinated People. The traveller must have received the last vaccination dose that is necessary for full vaccination at least 14 days before the date of travel, and the vaccine the person has received must be among those listed on the website of the Paul Ehrlich Institute.   For people not yet vaccinated entry from other countries is only possible in exceptional cases and is conditional on there being an urgent need.   Quarantine: Under the Ordinance on Coronavirus Entry Regulations, persons entering Germany following a stay in a high-risk area or area of variant of concern in the last ten days must proceed directly to their destination following entry and self-isolate there (quarantine). After a stay in a high-risk area travellers must self-isolate for 10 days, after a stay in an area of variant of concern for 14 days.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211224175315/https://www.auswaertiges-amt.de/en/visa-service/EinreiseUndAufenthalt#content_3

There is general availability of the vaccine to people 12 and older. It is still noted that those people who have an increased risk of severe or fatal courses of a COVID-19 disease, for example due to old age or certain pre-existing conditions, received a vaccination [prioritized] offer. Furthermore, this included groups of people who are either particularly exposed professionally or have close contacts of vulnerable groups of people â for example, medical staff or nurses. The prioritization was introduced with a new version of the Coronavirus Vaccination Ordinance as of June 7, 2021, as most people in the prioritization groups had received a vaccination offer in the meantime. In the meantime, all citizens aged 12 and over can arrange a vaccination appointment. https://web.archive.org/web/20220128160650/https://www.zusammengegencorona.de/impfen/basiswissen-zum-impfen/die-nationale-impfstrategie/

Vaccines are generally available for people aged 12+. For five- to eleven-year-old children without pre-existing conditions, there is currently only a low risk of severe Covid-19 disease, hospitalization and intensive care. In addition, the risk of rare side effects of vaccination cannot currently be estimated due to the limited data available. Therefore, the STIKO does not currently issue a general vaccination recommendation for five- to eleven-year-old children without pre-existing conditions. https://web.archive.org/web/20220128155639/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/coronavirus-impfung-faq-1788988  Recent guidance does call out the 50+ year old low vaccination rate as a risk, while agreeing to continue the measures taken so far & intensify their vaccination campaign this month: https://web.archive.org/web/20220126181808/https:/www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/974430/2000838/196ba96d5c9f415faf48dbb9178fc24f/2022-01-24-mpk-beschluss-data.pdf?download=1

Vaccination is easily available everywhere at no cost.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220126181808/https:/www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/974430/2000838/196ba96d5c9f415faf48dbb9178fc24f/2022-01-24-mpk-beschluss-data.pdf?download=1

Children in primary school will be sent home from Wednesday 15 December 2021 until (and including) Tuesday 4 January 2022.    While in school, however, Children and parents who have symptoms of COVID-19 are encouraged to follow the general recommendation to keep children home from school and get tested immediately. Pupils from 1st grade onwards and staff in primary and lower secondary school are strongly encouraged to get tested on a weekly basis, unless they are fully vaccinated or previously infected with COVID-19 within the last 6 months. Two weekly tests are recommended in municipalities and parishes with high infection rates.      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211231183502/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

There are no restrictions from February 1, but there are a number of recommendations to prevent infection. People with symptoms of COVID-19 are advised to self-isolate and be PCR-tested as soon as possible. Pupils with symptoms of COVID-19 should be kept separate from the other students and staff until they can be picked up or sent home.    Archived: https://archive.vn/ssWoy

There is no assembly ban or any restrictions on how many spectators may attend cultural and sporting events. Organizers of activities where many people gather standing indoors at the same time, and where there may therefore be a particularly high risk of the spread of infection, may consider taking steps to minimize the risk of infection in February. For an example this can be done by the organizer encouraging or facilitating that the participants are tested, or that an increased distance is operated at the event. For people entering Denmark from an EU and / or Schengen country or COVID-19 risk country, there is no requirement for isolation after entry.    However, those entering from a COVID-19 high-risk country must self-isolate after entry, unless they are fully vaccinated or previously infected. The isolation is required for 10 days but the isolation may be ended after a negative PCR test taken at the earliest on the sixth day after the time of entry.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211231184528/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/covidtravelrules

For people entering Denmark from an EU and / or Schengen country or COVID-19 risk country, there is no requirement for isolation after entry.    However, those entering from a COVID-19 high-risk country must self-isolate after entry, unless they are fully vaccinated or previously infected. The isolation is required for 10 days but the isolation may be ended after a negative PCR test taken at the earliest on the sixth day after the time of entry.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220120183111/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/covidtravelrules

People are fully vaccinated or previously infected and able to document this, for example with a corona passport,  can enter from all countries without test or self-isolation.    FOR THE UNVACCINATED OR THOSE WHO WERE PREVIOUSLY UNINFECTED:    - Entry from countries in EU/Schengen: A test must be taken within 24 hours after entry.    - Entry from COVID-19 risk countries: A test must be taken within 24 hours after entry.    - Entry from all other countries (high risk countries): A test must be taken within 24 hours after entry within 24 hours after entry. Furthermore, there is self-isolation for 10 days. The isolation may be ended with a negative PCR-test taken at least six days after arrival. Certain travellers (e.g. children under 15) are exempt from test and isolation requirements.    Archived: https://archive.vn/gXTNP

From 1 February 2022 there are no longer any restrictions in the social and elderly area. Thus there are no longer a requirement for corona passport for visitors etc. and requirements for the use of face mask or shield for visitors, etc. and employees on social services, etc.     If possible it is urged to continue arrangements for the display of corona passport and for the use of face mask/shield in nursing homes and social services with vulnerable residents/users. It is also urged with a continued focus on the test effort in relation to employees in the elderly care and on social services as well as visitors to nursing homes and social services. Social distancing measures and masks are recommended in formal and informal education. Participants in informal education, hobby activities, refresher training and youth work who are over 18 years of age have to present a valid COVID certificate proving vaccination or recovery.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211128160608/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/education-pre-schools-hobby-education-sport-continuous-education/restrictions-in-education-youth-work-hobby-and-sports-activities

Distance Learning is recommended. Social distancing measures and masks are recommended in formal and informal education. Participants in informal education, hobby activities, refresher training and youth work who are over 18 years of age have to present a valid COVID certificate proving vaccination or recovery. Otherwise, participants may need to present with a medical certificate affirming that vaccination is contraindicated to the person for health reasons.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220130230356/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/education-pre-schools-hobby-education-sport-continuous-education/restrictions-in-education-youth-work-hobby-and-sports-activities  http://web.archive.org/web/20220130231531/https://kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/levels-risk

Workplaces are open but the employers must evaluate the risks present in the working environment and enact measures to lower the risks: these measures can include requirement to wear a mask, testing, vaccination, re-organisation of work, etc.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220115161323/https://www.kriis.ee/en/work-life-and-being-away-work/employee/working-workplace

Since January 6th 2022, the country went into high risk level for covid-19 which means that distance working is highly recommended, in addition to the previous existing measures.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220115161323/https://www.kriis.ee/en/work-life-and-being-away-work/employee/working-workplace  https://web.archive.org/web/20220115162302/https://kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/levels-risk  https://web.archive.org/web/20220115162911/https://www.kriis.ee/en/news/risk-level-spread-coronavirus-became-very-high-again

Since January 27th 2022, the country went into very high risk level for covid-19 which means that distance working is highly recommended, in addition to the previous existing measures.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220130231121/https://www.kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions#distants  http://web.archive.org/web/20220130231531/https://kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/levels-risk

Participants over the age of 12 must present a covid certificate, else they cannot participate.   Provided that the organiser ensures that the infection risk status of all the participants is checked, up to 1000 people may participate indoors and up to 2 000 people outdoors. Events must end before 11pm.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220115155930/https://www.kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions

Non-vaccinated:   If vaccination is contraindicated to a person for health reasons, a corresponding medical certificate needs to be presented in order to participate.    Vaccinated:   Public meetings and events are allowed but participants who are 18 years old and older have to present a COVID certificate stating vaccination or recovery. Young people from the age of 12 years and three months up to 17 years (included) have to present a certificate proving vaccination or recovery or a certificate proving a negative result of a PCR or antigen RT test done by a health care service provider in order to participate.    Provided that the organiser ensures that the infection risk status of all the participants is checked, up to 1000 people may participate indoors and up to 2 000 people outdoors.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220130231121/https://www.kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions#distants

Participants over the age of 12 must present a covid certificate. People without covid certificate cannot participate in public gatherings. Recommendations are made to protect elderly people.   Where possible, home-based services provided for the elderly by the local government of residence should be preferred to placement in a nursing home.  Residents of nursing homes should not be transferred between different homes.  Before meeting a person at risk, make sure you are safe from infection and ensure safety when meeting them: wear a mask, keep your distance, and clean your hands and surfaces.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220115164650/https://www.kriis.ee/en/sickness-health-vaccinations/coronavirus-and-preventing-its-spread/prevention-coronavirus

The Nationwide Telework recommendation has now been reintroduced in areas currently experiencing increased levels of community transmission.   The recommendation is for all employees in the public sector to work remotely as extensively as possible if their duties so allow. The Government also recommends that private employers adopt similar extensive remote work practices, recognising, however, that workplaces will determine how to combine in-office and remote work in a way that ensures health security.     Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211216145328/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/-/10623/government-recommends-remote-work-in-areas-in-the-community-transmission-phase-until-further-notice

Vaccinated travelers from all countries are now permitted to enter Finland. However, this requires having received the last dose of a valid COVID-19 vaccine at least 14 days prior to arrival. People coming in from countries marked as risk countries who do no not have a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test, proof of having had the disease or a vaccination certificate, would have to be tested for COVID-19 on entry into the country. This test is mandatory    Archived: https://archive.vn/SVEDj

The requirements for entry into Finland include the following:   - a certificate of a full approved COVID-19 vaccination series, OR  - a certificate of having had the COVID-19 disease and one approved COVID-19 vaccine, OR  - an EU Digital COVID Certificate for a COVID-19 disease had less than six months ago, AND  - a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test taken no earlier than 48 hours before arrival in Finland.    These requirements apply to those born in or before 2006. They however do not apply to citizens of Finland, those with permanent residence in Finland or persons travelling for essential reasons. Those who do not meet the requirement are required to have a mandatory covid test.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220106182331/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic

A mobile app "Koronavilkku",  is a contact tracing app was produced by the Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) to help people find out whether you may have been exposed to coronavirus. The app can also be used to send share positive tests results anonymously with those you have been in close contact with.      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210820141655/https://koronavilkku.fi/en

The Finnish Institute of Health and Welfare recommends a third dose of coronavirus vaccine for    - persons with severe immunodeficiency and aged 12 or over  - persons who have been vaccinated with a short interval of less than 6 weeks and are aged 18 or over  all persons aged 60 and over  - persons living in institutions and care homes and aged 18 or over  - persons in medical high-risk groups 1 and 2 and aged 18 or over health care personnel who treat coronavirus patients, personnel of 24-hour care facilities and other social welfare and health care personnel providing urgent care. Overall policy remains broadly similar to that introduced on 9 December 2021, but isolation and testing rules to be followed after the detection of a case of Covid-19 in a class have been modified from 3 January 2022 per https://web.archive.org/web/20220105124117/https://www.gouvernement.fr/les-regles-d-isolement-en-vigueur-en-milieu-scolaire-depuis-le-3-janvier     https://web.archive.org/web/20220108050328/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

Covid-19 protocols in schools have been simplified in order to allow education facilities to remain open. The following regulations, announced by the Prime Minister on 10 January, take effect as of 14 January:     - When a positive case is detected in a class, parents will no longer be asked to pick up their child immediately, they can wait for the end of the school day.  - When a positive case is detected in a classroom, case contacts aged under 12 years or those aged over 12 who have a complete vaccination schedule will be able to use 3 free self-tests provided by pharmacies, and will no longer have to perform a PCR or antigen test followed by two self-tests).  - Parents will no longer be asked to produce a certificate after each self-test: a single certificate will be requested. Children may not attend school if one of the self-tests is positive.     Additional measures were announced by the Minister of Education, Youth and Sports on 13 January, including:     - the distribution of 5 million FFP2 masks in establishments for staff who feel the need;  - the replenishment of the fund for the purchase of CO2 sensors as much as necessary, so that local authorities can request it even more massively.  - the recruitment of 3,300 more contract workers;  - the use of supplementary lists;  - the recruitment of educational assistants and support staff for school principals.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220114193949/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education
No policy changes - https://web.archive.org/web/20220121172851/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

From 6 January, the classification of countries returns to the 3-stage system of Green/Orange/Red with the elimination of the temporary fourth "Scarlet Red" category. Countries of the travellers origin are categorised as follows:     "Green" countries/territories: countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, South Korea, The United Arab Emirates, Hong Kong, Japan, Kuwait, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, Taiwan, Uruguay and Vanuatu.    "Orange" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries/territories. Reinforced measures are in force for travel between France and the United Kingdom. The Travel Advice sheet for the United Kingdom should be consulted.    "Red" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus with the presence of variants of concern is observed. These are: Afghanistan, Belarus, Botswana, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Georgia, Lesotho, Malawi, Mauritius, Moldova, Montenegro, Mozambique, Namibia, Nigeria, Pakistan, Russia, South Africa, Suriname, Tanzania, Turkey, Ukraine, the United States, Zambia and Zimbabwe.    All passengers from Red list countries must present negative results of a PCR or antigen test taken in the previous 48 hours at boarding and may be tested again on arrival. Unvaccinated passengers are subject to presentation of "compelling reasons" for travel, mandatory antigen testing on arrival, and must quarantine for 10 days under the control of security forces.     Passengers from Orange list countries must present negative results of a PCR or antigen test taken in the previous 48 hours at boarding. Vaccinated passengers are not subject to the "compelling reasons" regime, but unvaccinated people are and must commit to self-isolation lasting 7 days and undergo testing at the end of this period.     Although an Orange list country, additional regulations apply to all passengers aged 12 or over arriving from the United Kingdom:     - subject to the list of "compelling reasons"  - must present a negative PCR or antigenic (TAG) test taken less than 24 hours before the flight on boarding ;  - must register before departure on the eOS-COVID digital platform  ;  - may be tested antigen on arrival ;  - will be subject to mandatory isolation for 10 days,supervised and controlled by the security forces. This isolation obligation may be lifted from 48 hours, subject to being able to justify a negative test (PCR or TAG).    Specific guidance for UK passengers is available at https://web.archive.org/web/20220108054040/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/conseils-par-pays-destination/royaume-uni/    Passengers from Green List countries are divided into two groups:     1. Member States of the European Union, Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, the Holy See and Switzerland - Travelers twelve years of age or older who do not have proof of a complete vaccination schedule or a certificate of recovery from Covid-19 must present before travel the negative result of a test (PCR or antigenic) of less than 24 hours. They may be tested for antigen on arrival.    2. Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, Hong Kong, Japan, Kuwait, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, South Korea, Taiwan, The United Arab Emirates, Uruguay and Vanuatu:  All travelers twelve years of age or older, regardless of their vaccination status,from these countries/territories must present for boarding, the negative result of a PCR test or an antigen test (TAG) carried out less than 48 hours before the flight.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220108050616/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

From 24 January, the classification of countries on the 3-stage system of Green/Orange/Red has been adjusted with some countires and territories moving from Red or Green status to Orange. Countries of the travellers origin are categorised as follows:     "Green" countries/territories: countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, South Korea, the United Arab Emirates, Hong Kong, Japan, Kuwait, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Senegal, Taiwan, Uruguay and Vanuatu. (previously, Argentina and Australia were on the Green list, but have moved to Orange)    "Orange" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries/territories. Reinforced measures are in force for travel between France and the United Kingdom. The Travel Advice sheet for the United Kingdom should be consulted.    "Red" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus with the presence of variants of concern is observed. These are: Afghanistan, Belarus, the United States, Georgia, Mauritius, Montenegro, Nigeria, Pakistan, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Suriname, Tanzania, Turkey. (previously, Botswana, Lesotho, Malawi, Moldova, Mozambique, Namibia, Russia, South Africa, Ukraine, Zambia and Zimbabwe were on the Red list, and have now moved to Orange)    All passengers from Red list countries must present negative results of a PCR or antigen test taken in the previous 48 hours at boarding and may be tested again on arrival. Unvaccinated passengers are subject to presentation of "compelling reasons" for travel, mandatory antigen testing on arrival, and must quarantine for 10 days under the control of security forces.     Passengers from Orange list countries must present negative results of a PCR or antigen test taken in the previous 48 hours at boarding. Vaccinated passengers are not subject to the "compelling reasons" regime, but unvaccinated people are and must commit to self-isolation lasting 7 days and undergo testing at the end of this period.     Although an Orange list country, additional regulations apply to all passengers aged 12 or over arriving from the United Kingdom from 14 January:     - All travelers, vaccinated or not, must present a negative test (PCR or antigen test) taken less than 24 hours before travel  - For vaccinated travellers, there is no longer any obligation to justify a compelling reason to come to France, nor an obligation to respect a period of isolation on arrival on the national territory. As such, the need to register, prior to travel, on the digital platform "eOS passenger" is lifted. Screenings on arrival may be conducted at the places of arrival. In the event of a positive result, the traveller will be placed in solitary confinement.  - For unvaccinated travellers, travel to or from the United Kingdom is permitted provided that it can prove compelling reasons valid for "red" countries.  - Unvaccinated travellers from the United Kingdom must continue to register, before their departure, on the eOS passenger digital platform, allowing them to enter the address of their stay in France. They must, upon arrival in France, observe a strict quarantine period of 10 days at this place; this quarantine will be controlled by law enforcement.    Specific guidance for UK passengers is available at https://web.archive.org/web/20220117202519/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/deplacements#voyager_dans_l'union_europeenne    Passengers from Green List countries are divided into two groups:     1. Member States of the European Union, Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, the Holy See and Switzerland - Travelers twelve years of age or older who do not have proof of a complete vaccination schedule or a certificate of recovery from Covid-19 must present before travel the negative result of a test (PCR or antigenic) of less than 24 hours. They may be tested for antigen on arrival.    2. Bahrain, Hong Kong, Japan, Kuwait, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, South Korea, Taiwan, The United Arab Emirates, Uruguay and Vanuatu:  All travelers twelve years of age or older, regardless of their vaccination status,from these countries/territories must present for boarding, the negative result of a PCR test or an antigen test (TAG) carried out less than 48 hours before the flight. They may be tested for antigen on arrival.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220128204055/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

Vaccination is universally available to people aged 5 and over.     Vaccination boosters are available to all people aged 18 and over from three months after the last injection or infection with Covid-19.    People aged 80 and over are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220108050823/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

All travellers 12 years and older are required to get tested for COVID-19 upon arrival in the Faroe Islands. Younger travellers can voluntarily get tested.  All travellers are recommended to home quarantine until the result from the PCR test from the second day after arrival is available.  If you arrive from a âhigh-riskâ country, you should home quarantine for seven days. This period can be shortened if you can show a negative PCR test result taken no more than six days after arrival in the Faroes.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220104081708/https://korona.fo/travel?_l=en  https://web.archive.org/web/20211222162315/https://korona.fo/270?_l=en

England's Plan B measures are to end from Thursday 27 January. Covid passports dropped meaning all businesses are open, without any requirement to present a pass to get in. Mandatory Covid passports for entering nightclubs and large events would end, though organisations could choose to use the NHS Covid pass if they wished. People would no longer be advised to work from home and should discuss their return to offices with employers  Face masks will no longer be mandated, though people are still advised to wear coverings in enclosed or crowded spaces and when meeting strangers.    Covid passes still required in other devolved nations for access to some businesses so coding remains at a 2, but now Targeted not General    http://web.archive.org/web/20220121121233/https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-60047438

In Northern Ireland 'No more than 30 people can meet in a private home and stay overnight. Regulations remain in place that prevent gatherings/ parties of more than 30 people in domestic settings.'    https://archive.vn/rXYXV

Northern Ireland- recommendations remain in place    Travel  You should avoid visiting places where there is a chance that large numbers of people will gather and crowds will form.  If you go somewhere and there are crowds which will make social distancing difficult, consider going somewhere else instead.  When travelling you should walk, cycle or use private transport, shared only with members of your household where possible.  If possible, you should avoid car sharing with people from outside of your household. If you are car sharing, as well as wearing a face covering, good ventilation in the car is vitally important - particularly by keeping a window open.    https://archive.vn/rXYXV

Changes to be introduced 11 February for fully vaccinated travellers    Mr Speaker, from 4am on the 11th February, and in time for the half-term break, eligible fully vaccinated passengers arriving in the UK will no longer have to take a post-arrival, lateral flow test.    Today I can announce that passengers who do not qualify as fully vaccinated will no longer be required to do a day 8 test after arrival or, indeed, to self-isolate. They will still need to fill out a passenger locator form to demonstrate proof of a negative COVID test taken 2 days before travel, and they must also take a post-arrival PCR test.      https://archive.vn/FNxIc

In line with a decision made by the Coordination Council, citizens of Georgia will be allowed to enter the following facilities with a Green Passport from December 1, 2021: indoor or outdoor eateries, restaurants, cafes and bars; cinemas, theatres, operas, museums, concert halls, entertainment centers, casinos and gambling centers; spas, fitness centers, hotels and cable lifts of ski resorts. The referred requirement will apply to visitors of the listed facilities. As for the entertainment centers for children, Green Passport will be required from citizens aged 18 and older. An individual will have a green status, if s/he is vaccinated, has a PCR test valid for 72 hours or antigen test valid for 24 hours or has been infected with a novel coronavirus. Night clubs remain banned both outdoors and indoors.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220130173058/https://stopcov.gov.ge/en/page/restrictions-list

Border crossing is currently permitted to citizens of EU member states and 40 countries   in addition, as well as to individuals with a permission of residence. They need to present the following at the border crossing: document evidencing a full cycle of vaccination and a negative result of PCR test obtained in the past 72 hours, or alternatively present only a negative PCR test result obtained 72 hours prior to the visit to Georgia and get a repeated PCR test on the 3rd day of their stay in Georgia at their own expense.  When entering the country, foreign nationals who have had COVID-19 and are vaccinated with one dose, will be subject to the same regulation as applicable to individuals vaccinated with both doses.  Georgian citizens vaccinated in Georgia and entering the country through land borders are exempt from mandatory PCR testing.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220130173058/https://stopcov.gov.ge/en/page/restrictions-list  Mandatory 14-day quarantine, followed by a PCR test is imposed on anyone who has been in South Africa, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Namibia, Lesotho, Eswatini, Mozambique or Malawi in the previous 14-day period.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220130181211/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/georgia/entry-requirements

Greece will reopen schools as scheduled on Monday amid record coronavirus cases, the government has decided.    Schools will reopen on Jan. 10 with stricter testing protocols as ânothing can replace live teaching for the psycho-emotional development of our children,â Education Minister Niki Kerameus said Tuesday.    https://web.archive.org/web/%2A/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-01-04/greece-to-reopen-schools-as-planned-on-monday-amid-record-cases

Greece reintroduced measures aimed at curbing the spread of the coronavirus pandemic amid concern that rising cases will pile pressure on the nationâs health care system.    As much as 50% of all private and public-sector employees will have to work from home between Jan. 3 and Jan. 16, Health Minister Athanasios Plevris said Monday. The government also ordered restaurants, bars, cafes and night clubs to close at midnight.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220110161816/https://www.bloomberg.com/tosv2.html?vid=&uuid=ea7e0e9d-7230-11ec-a53d-5a7175777570&url=L25ld3MvYXJ0aWNsZXMvMjAyMS0xMi0yNy9ncmVlY2UtcmVpbnN0YXRlcy13b3JrLWZyb20taG9tZS1tYW5kYXRlLW5pZ2h0LWxpZmUtY3VyYnM=

The government last week reimposed a mask mandate for all indoor and outdoor spaces and canceled outdoor holiday festivities. A highly protective mask, or the use of double mask, will now be mandatory for those working in restaurants, Plevris said.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220110161816/https://www.bloomberg.com/tosv2.html?vid=&uuid=ea7e0e9d-7230-11ec-a53d-5a7175777570&url=L25ld3MvYXJ0aWNsZXMvMjAyMS0xMi0yNy9ncmVlY2UtcmVpbnN0YXRlcy13b3JrLWZyb20taG9tZS1tYW5kYXRlLW5pZ2h0LWxpZmUtY3VyYnM=

no policy change     Unless all passengers are members of the same family, a maximum of 3 persons are permitted to travel in a taxi or other private vehicle with up to 7 seats, or 4 persons in a private vehicle with up to 9 seats;  Cross-regional travel is allowed for mainland Greece and the islands of Lefkada, Evia and Salamina (use of self-tests ahead of travel is strongly recommended but is not mandatory).  Cross-regional travel to the rest of the islands is permitted but only with either:    proof of vaccination and 14 days since second dose (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status), or  a negative result from a PCR test carried out up to 72 hours prior to travel; or  a negative result from a rapid test or self-test conducted up to 24 hours before travel; or  a self-test declaration signed less than 24 hours before travel; or  documentary proof of having recovered from Covid-19 (at least 2 months since infection, and no more than 9 months)  Travel in Greece  Travel within Greece between Regional Units is permitted subject to adherence to public health measures as outlined above. You must wear a mask at all times on all public transport.    If you are travelling via ferry, you will need to complete a health questionnaire and hand it to the ferry operator before boarding. The necessary forms will be provided by the operator: you should contact them directly if you need further information. Temperature checks may also be carried out before boarding.    If you are travelling by internal (domestic) flights, specific measures relating to check-in, baggage allowances and other details are in place to reduce the spread of coronavirus. You should check with your operator directly for further detail.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210802101710/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus
no policy change   The government of Greece imposes a curfew between 00.00 to 06.00 in the red zones.   https://web.archive.org/https://covid19.gov.gr/covid-map-en/

no policy change     All unvaccinated people in Greece from Monday, September 13, will be allowed to board all means of transport for domestic travel between regions (airplanes, ferries, intercity trains and KTEL buses) only if they have a negative Covid-19 rapid antigen test result.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211022124338/https://news.gtp.gr/2021/09/13/covid-19-how-unvaccinated-greece-can-travel-by-land-air-sea-rules/

All those travelling to Greece (aged 5 or above) must show proof of a professionally administered negative rapid COVID-19 test taken no more than 24 hours before arrival or proof of a professionally administered negative PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before arrival.     The measure affects all arrivals, regardless of vaccination status or country of departure. The only exception is for arrivals who have spent less than 48 hours in a country prior to arriving in Greece.                                              Random antigen testing on arrival applies to every arrival to Greece, regardless of the certificate in their possession. If you are selected, please keep in mind that the screening is mandatory and in case of refusal, authorities reserve the right to refuse entry into the country.    If you are selected for a test and test positive, you will be subject to mandatory quarantine, for which you may be required by the Greek authorities to move to a designated quarantine facility.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220110161137/https://www.dfa.ie/travel/travel-advice/a-z-list-of-countries/greece/

In Greenland, there is a requirement that people aged 15 and older must be fully vaccinated if they want access to premises to which the public has access. Previously, a negative PCR test also gave access to such premises, but that is no longer possible.  -You must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19  -You are only allowed access to the following places if you are fully vaccinated against COVID-19:  1) Restaurants, cafes, pubs, discos and similar establishments.  2) Cultural institutions, including culture centres, cinemas, museums, exhibition halls, etc.  3) Community centres and similar establishments.  4) Libraries.  5) Indoor sports facilities, including sports colleges and sports halls, swimming pools, gyms, football pitches, etc.  6) Hairdressers, massage parlours, beauty clinics and similar establishments.  When are you fully vaccinated?  -People who have completed a full vaccination programme, for example two doses of Pfizer or Moderna vaccine or one dose of Johnson&Johnson vaccine, are considered fully vaccinated. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. This means that for the time being there is no requirement to get the booster vaccination to be considered fully vaccinated.  -If you have previously been infected with COVID-19 and can present documentation of a positive PCR test result which is between 14 days and 12 weeks old, you are covered by the same rules as if you were fully vaccinated.  *updated on 26Jan2022  https://web.archive.org/web/20211228235327/https://corona.nun.gl/en/corona-passport-digital-eu-covid-certificate/vaccination-as-a-requirement-for-access/

Stay at home and isolate if you have COVID-19 symptoms or have tested positive.  If you have COVID-19 symptoms or are infected with the coronavirus you should isolate.  To isolate means:  -You must stay at home and not meet with other people who you do not live with.  -You must avoid contact with the people you live with.  -You must pay special attention to good hygiene and cleaning.  If you have tested positive for the coronavirus and it is not possible to keep to a sufficient distance from others in your household, the municipality may possibly provide you with voluntary isolation accommodation outside the home. For example, if your home is very small or you share your household with people who are at an increased risk of serious illness from COVID-19. Call the coronavirus hotline and learn about your options.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206130814/https://corona.nun.gl/en/prevention/infection-prevention-advice/

Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated or a resident of Greenland or you are relocating to Greenland.    -In regard to entering Greenland, you are considered fully vaccinated 14 days after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. This means that for the time being there is no requirement to get the booster vaccination to be considered fully vaccinated.    When you intend to travel to Greenland, you must remember to do the following:  -You must have a negative COVID-19 PCR test from a Nordic country (Denmark, Sweden, Norway, Finland, Iceland, Faroe Islands), UK, Liechtenstein, Switzerland, or a country in EU that is maximum 48 hours old from the time of departure and have valid documentation showing this.  -Bring a face mask for the journey and wear it during the journey, on the plane and in the airport, and also during transport to your place of residence. This rule applies to everyone at 12 years old or older.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211220215011/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/conditions-for-entry-into-greenland/

Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -From January 26 2022 and onwards, there is no longer a requirement to present a negative PCR test upon entry into Greenland.  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated or a resident of Greenland or you are relocating to Greenland.  -In regard to entering Greenland, you are considered fully vaccinated immediately after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. This means that for the time being there is no requirement to get the booster vaccination to be considered fully vaccinated.    When you intend to travel to Greenland, you must remember to do the following:  -Documentation of your vaccine status  -Certificate of residence or something else that documents that you are a resident of Greenland (applies to unvaccinated citizens who are living in Greenland)  -Bring a face mask for the journey and wear it during the journey, on the plane and in the airport, and also during transport to your place of residence. -This rule applies to everyone at 12 years old or older.  -Special rules apply if you have previously been infected with COVID-19 within the last 12 weeks. Read more in the section âPreviously infected with COVID-19â here.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129073108/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/conditions-for-entry-into-greenland/

*Updated guidelines  If you receive a SMS with a positive test result, you should:   -Isolate   -Inform your close contacts  -Wait for a call from the health department / corona secretariat  This applies regardless of whether you are fully vaccinated or not, and whether you have symptoms or not.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117024228/https://corona.nun.gl/en/infection-and-symptoms/if-you-test-positive/

Test result:  -If your test is positive, it means you are infected with the coronavirus.  -If your COVID-19 test is positive, you will receive your test result via SMS. You are responsible for contacting your close contacts. Read more about the definition of a close contact.  -If you have taken an antigen test (home test) which shows a positive result, you should consider yourself infected with COVID-19. You must follow the same guidelines, but you will not be contacted by the healthcare system.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206141614/https://corona.nun.gl/en/infection-and-symptoms/if-you-test-positive/
No changes noted.

Use of face masks and visors:  -Face masks can be used as a supplement for preventing the spread of infection in situations where it is difficult to keep to distance. It is important that you continue to follow the advice relating to keeping a distance and good hygiene even when you wear a face mask.    In Greenland, you must wear a face mask in the following situations:  -All individuals aged 12 years or older on domestic or international flights (face masks must be worn to the quarantine location/end destination).  -If you have been infected or risk of being infected with COVID-19 and in exceptional circumstances must move outside, e.g. because you need to get tested.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129080932/https://corona.nun.gl/en/prevention/use-of-face-masks-and-visors/

Restrictions for Individuals and Businesses  Businesses and individuals may be restricted due to the epidemiological measures based on your location in Croatia.    As of January 10, 2022, the Government of Croatia is imposing a range of epidemiological measures:    Indoor public gatherings are limited to 25 people.  Outdoor public gatherings are limited to no more than 50 people.  Outdoor public gatherings where everyone has EU digital certificates are limited to 200.  Private ceremonies will be limited to 20. Exception: private ceremonies in which everyone has a covid certificate will be limited to 50 people.  Sporting events and competitions: Indoor sports facilities may operate with up to 20 percent of spectator seating occupied. Outdoor events may operate with up to 40 percent of spectator seating occupied.  Catering / Dining establishments will be under more robust and compliance checks.  Individual counties and cities may have additional measures. Please visit?the?Croatian Governmentâs COVID-19 website?for additional information.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220125001728/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Professional artistic performances, cultural programs and events attended only by persons (visitors, performers and staff) holding an EU digital COVID certificate of vaccination, testing and / or recovery from COVID-19 are exempt from all restrictions of this recommendation - including the obligation to wear masks, physical distances, number of persons present, etc. Also, if all contractors have an EU digital COVID certificate, they are exempt from all anti-epidemic measures.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220129104111/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-svakodnevnom-zivotu/preporuke-za-sprjecavanje-zaraze-covid-19-tijekom-odrzavanja-profesionalnih-umjetnickih-izvedbi-kulturnih-programa-i-manifestacija/740

The measure of banning all public events and outdoor gatherings attended by more than 100 people in one place is still valid, unless it is a public event or gathering attended only by persons with an EU digital COVID certificate .    https://web.archive.org/web/20211117225936/https://koronavirus.hr/od-06-11-ogranicenja-za-okupljanja-a-od-15-11-covid-potvrde-u-drzavnim-i-javnim-slu%C5%BEbama-uklju%C4%8Dujuci-i-skole/992
