Mass events can now go ahead under strict restrictions. Events have been categorised into low, medium and high risk:  - Low risk: capacity of 100 or 50% of venue maximum capacity. Defined as events where participants are wearing masks, food and drinks are prohibited, sitting is mandatory, and event takes place without singing, encouragement or other loud vocal expressions.  - Medium risk: capacity of 100 or 25% of venue maximum capacity. Defined as events where participants are wearing masks and here is a fixed sitting or standing arrangement.   - High risk: capacity of 20 people. Defined as events in a public catering operation or a non-low-risk mass event and a medium-risk mass event; this includes weddings, parties and other celebrations.   All mass event attendees must be fully vaccinated or have proof of full COVID-19 recovery within the past 90 days. Funerals are exempt from these restrictions, as are meetings of public authorities, elections, and mass events necessary for the course of the following professional competitions in selected sports.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220123200410/https://korona.gov.sk/obmedzenia-pre-hromadne-podujatia/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220123195717/https://www.uvzsr.sk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4988%3Ainformacia-k-novym-vyhlakam-uvz-sr-respiratory-hromadne-podujatia-prevadzky-otp-na-pracoviskach&catid=56%3Atlaove-spravy&Itemid=62

All mass event attendees must be fully vaccinated; those who are unvaccinated must have proof of full COVID-19 recovery within the past 90 days. Defined as events where participants are wearing masks, food and drinks are prohibited, sitting is mandatory, and event takes place without singing, encouragement or other loud vocal expressions.  - Medium risk: capacity of 100 or 25% of venue maximum capacity. Defined as events where participants are wearing masks and here is a fixed sitting or standing arrangement.   - High risk: capacity of 20 people. Defined as events in a public catering operation or a non-low-risk mass event and a medium-risk mass event; this includes weddings, parties and other celebrations.   Funerals are exempt from these restrictions, as are meetings of public authorities, elections, and mass events necessary for the course of the following professional competitions in selected sports. Everyone aged over 12 years and 2 months arriving from all countries by all means of transport must register in advance of travel by completing the âEhranicaâ form on the Slovak governmentâs website. For those who are not EU citizens and are entering the country unvaccinated, an isolation period of at least 10 days is required. Persons who have visited South Africa, Botswana, Namibia, Lesotho, Eswatini, Mozambique, Zimbabwe, in the last 14 days prior to entering Slovakia must undergo isolation for at least 14 days, regardless of vaccination status. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211229122248/https://www.mic.iom.sk/en/news/637-covid-19-measures.html & http://web.archive.org/web/20220123203847/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovakia/coronavirus

Those over 60 are advised to:  - stay away from the sick and limit all close contact, avoiding crowds as much as possible.   - avoid traveling on public transport.  - only go out when necessary, such as buying groceries.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220123215417/https://korona.gov.sk/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Osoby_s_vyssim_rizikom_ochorenia_COVID-19.pdf

The Recovered - Vaccinated - Tested rule mandatory for all employees  The Government ordinance stipulates that the Recovered - Vaccinated â Tested rule (RVT rule*) must be met by all employees as well as all users of services or activities, except in cases of the emergency supply of basic necessities of life, the provision of public order, security and defence, emergency medical assistance and protection and rescue, urgent healthcare services, urgent procedures involving social and family issues, urgent personal assistance, and protection and rescue.  Employees  The RVT rule must be met for the duration of work by all employees and persons who work for an employer on another legal basis, or are self-employed. The requirements of the RVT rule do not have to be met while a person is working from home.  https://archive.vn/ZCO4V#selection-1117.0-1173.71

https://archive.vn/ZCO4V#selection-1643.0-1647.108  The organisation of public cultural events in open public spaces is not permitted, but it is permitted in enclosed public spaces with fixed seating, whereby every other seat must be left vacant, the use of face masks is mandatory, and all participants must comply with the recovered/vaccinated/tested rule.    Public cultural events may only be held on condition that the performers and people involved in the organisation of the event that have direct contact with visitors meet the requirements of the recovered/vaccinated/tested rule. This condition does not apply to persons under the age of 12. The public cultural event can be attended by a maximum of 750 visitors.

Education continues to operate in person, but distance learning is recommended wherever possible (esp. at university level): https://archive.ph/guIOp

Primary school, high school and special high school  The overriding principle is still in-person education.  Measures should be taken, such as being outdoors as much as possible, avoiding congregating in large groups indoors, and where possible avoiding mixing different classes.    Adult education and higher education institutions  Partially remote learning is recommended for higher education institutions, to create distance inside the lecture rooms, but will not apply as a fulltime measure.    Practical classes, such as examinations, and other adult education should be continued with risk-reducing measures in place.    https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations
Recommendation to work from home wherever possible; has not changed since last data entry: https://archive.ph/guIOp
Public events (indoor) with more than 50 people cannot take place without a covid certification: https://archive.ph/guIOp

Public gatherings and public events  For indoor events with more than 20 and a maximum of 50 participants, all participants must be seated, groups must be limited to a maximum of 8 people, and a distance of one metre must be kept between parties. Vaccination certificates can be used.  For indoor events with more than 50 participants, vaccination certificates must be used, together with assigned seats, and a distance of one meter must be kept between parties.  For public gatherings and events, as well as exhibitions/fairs indoors, with vaccination pass requirements, the maximum number of participants will be 500. If the premises are sectioned, and participants from different sections do not get in contact with those from other sections, each section can have maximum 500 participants.  Special instructions apply to religious events and are outlined in the current regulations.    Fairs  Maximum 500 visitors for trade fairs. An organizer can divide the gathering or event into sections. Then the maximum ceiling applies to each individual section.    Organisers must determine the maximum number of visitors and exhibitors based on the requirement of 10 square metres per person.    Private gatherings in rented premises   Private gatherings held in rented premises can have a maximum of 20 participants. This does not apply to funeral ceremonies. Funeral ceremonies and moments of remembrance will be exempt and can thus have 50 participants.    Venues serving food and drink  The size of parties is limited to eight people.  Guests must be seated, with at least one meter between the groups.  Venues must close no later than 11 pm, which means that the venue has to be empty at 11 pm.   Indoor trading establishments and markets  Trading establishments must determine the maximum number of visitors based on the requirement of 10 square metres per person.  Places with cultural and leisure activities   At least 10 square metres per person is required.  There are exceptions for businesses that are focused on children and young people, for example sports practice and competitions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220125155512/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations

Recommendation to stay at home & reduce contacts wherever possible was introduced: https://archive.ph/guIOp

19th Jan 2022, Sweden Removes Pre-Entry Testing Requirement    Travellers are no longer considered to represent a particular risk that would affect the spread of the Omicron variant in Sweden. For this reason, the specific requirement for a negative COVID-19 result from a test conducted within 48 hours of arrival to Sweden is no longer considered to be a proportional measure.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220121190528/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/sweden-removes-pre-entry-testing-requirement/

A ban on entry to Sweden is in effect for non-essential travel from most countries outside the EU/EEA. The ban does not apply to Swedish citizens, citizens of another EU/EEA country or citizens from a number of exempt countries. Swedish citizens and foreign nationals who are registered in Sweden are always entitled to travel into Sweden.    Read more under International travel, where you will find information about which countries are exempt from the entry ban and what is needed in order to be granted an exemption from the entry ban.     Foreign nationals aged 18 or more travelling to Sweden from countries within the EU/EEA or the Nordic countries must present the EU Covid certificate or proof of vaccination against Covid-19 from certain other countries. Foreign nationals travelling to Sweden from other countries must be exempted from the travel ban and show evidence of a negative test of Covid-19, from within the past 72 hours. More information in Swedish at Regeringen.se.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220125155512/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations
Coordinated public campaign in place: https://archive.ph/guIOp

Recommendation to wear face masks in public transportation: "The Public Health Agency of Sweden emphasises the importance of using face masks when many people travel together."  https://archive.ph/guIOp#selection-2985.117-2985.231

Most services are available in Turkey without restrictions.  As of 6th September 2021 proof of vaccination or a negative PCR test within the past 48 hours is required to enter some establishments hosting crowded events such as theaters or cinemas. This requirement applies to individuals 18 years old and older including foreign nationals with Turkish residency.  Individuals who fail to provide the necessary documentation will not be permitted to enter into these venues or participate in crowded events.   http://web.archive.org/web/20220123182623/https://tr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

Buses, ferries, and trains are operating but there are limits to passenger capacity on buses and all passengers must wear a mask.?? This requirement applies to individuals 18 years old and older including foreign nationals with Turkish residency. Individuals who fail to provide the necessary documentation will not be permitted to board public transportation.   http://web.archive.org/web/20220123182623/https://tr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

As of 6th  September 2021, intercity travel by bus, plane, train or other public transportation requires proof of vaccination or a negative PCR test taken within the past 48 hours. This requirement applies to individuals 18 years old and older including foreign nationals with Turkish residency. Travel using a private vehicle will not require proof of vaccination or a negative PCR test. Individuals who fail to provide the necessary documentation will not be permitted to board public transportation.   http://web.archive.org/web/20220123182623/https://tr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

A PCR test is required for individuals over the age of 12 years old who are unable to show proof of vaccination.  Passengers arriving in Turkey?will be required to complete an information form and will be checked for symptoms. Passengers may be subject to a PCR test by means of the method of sampling at points of arrival in Turkey. If their test results are positive, they shall be taken under treatment in accordance with the COVID-19 Guidelines of the Ministry of Health. The passengers with positive test results and persons having been in close contact with such passengers shall be taken under quarantine for a period of 7 days at the addresses they have determined, and if the results of the PCR tests to be taken at the end of the 5th day are negative, the quarantine shall be ended. The quarantines of these people who are identified to have Delta variant shall be ended upon submitting a negative PCR test result at the end of the 7th day.    Passengers must have a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken at most 72 hours before arrival, if arriving from or they have been in Afghanistan, South Africa, Botswana, Mozambique, Namibia, Zimbabwe, Brazil, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, India and Pakistan in the last 14 days (This does not apply to passengers under 12). Passengers arriving from Egypt and Iran must have a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken at most 72 hours before arrival (This does not apply to passengers under 12). Effective 10th January 2022, passengers arriving from a country other than above countries do not need to submit negative PCR /rapid antigen test if they fit into one of the following categories; passengers younger than 12 years; passengers with a COVID-19 vaccination certificate showing that they were fully vaccinated at least 14 days before arrival; passengers with a COVID-19 recovery certificate issued at most 6 months before arrival; merchant seamen.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220123182623/https://tr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

Contact Turkish Ministry of Health ALO 184 for the notification of new COVID-19 cases. No evidence of manual contact tracing found.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220123204057/https://covid19.tubitak.gov.tr/en/prevention-and-treatment-methods/case-notification

The wearing of masks is mandatory at all times outside the home throughout Turkey. This includes, but is not limited to, all public places, including streets, side streets, parks, gardens, picnic areas, markets, sea side and public transportation including Metro, buses, taxis and ferries. Masks are also mandatory in all shops, restaurants, hairdressers and barber shops.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220123205055/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkey/coronavirus

Vaccination is available for anyone over 15. Children between the ages of 12 and 15 are eligible for shots if they suffer from a chronic disease.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220123210539/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/covid-19-jabs-for-under-12s-not-on-agenda-turkish-health-minister/news    COVID-19 vaccines administered at designated healthcare facilities providing vaccination services are completely free of charge, courtesy of the Turkish Ministry of Health.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220123205447/https://covid19asi.saglik.gov.tr/EN-78316/frequently-asked-questions.html

Limited to 50 people. Further no more than 1 person per 5 square meters.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220118001750/https://covid19.gov.ua/en

As before, for inter-state travel between regions in the yellow (in which the whole country is) and red phase, passengers in buses, trains and planes need to show a vaccination card, test result or recovery confirmation. This rule does not apply to passenger cars.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220118001943/https://covid19.gov.ua/karantynni-zakhody

For all travellers, there is a requirement to show test result, vaccination card or recovery confirmation upon arrival. People that spent time in specific countries are required to quarantine, regardless of their documents (the list includes: the Republic of South Africa, the Republic of Botswana, Zimbabwe, Namibia, the Kingdom of Lesotho, the Kingdom of Eswatini, the Republic of Mozambique and the Republic of Malawi). Foreigners travelling from these countries (with some exceptions) are not allowed to enter the country.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220118001648/https://covid19.gov.ua/border
Increases in unemployment benefits and better treatment for some groups (e.g. that quitted work).  https://web.archive.org/web/20220118004045/https://covid19.gov.ua/prohramy-sotsialnoi-pidtrymky

Multiple measures to help business including some tax breaks.   The National Bank of Ukraine recommended that banks introduce a special grace period for servicing loans during the quarantine period for individuals and businesses. Banks have several options for loan restructuring:  (i) Full or partial exemption from payment of the loan body for the period of quarantine with the corresponding extension of the loan. (ii) Capitalization of interest payments.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220118004144/https://covid19.gov.ua/prohramy-pidtrymky-biznesu
Centralised public campaign organised by the ministry of health.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220118001750/https://covid19.gov.ua/en
Testing is generally available, but is not free.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220118001750/https://covid19.gov.ua/en
There seems to exist some contact tracing, but the degree of thoroughness is unclear  https://web.archive.org/web/20220118001750/https://covid19.gov.ua/en

As earlier, masks are required in public transport, mass events and business are required to provide protective equipment to their employees. More generally mask-wearing is required in indoor public spaces.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220118001750/https://covid19.gov.ua/en
